div.head: Interest in the Childhood and Juvenilia of Ruskin by the Ruskin Family and Circle
div.p: W. G. Collingwood believed that Ruskinʼs parents “encouraged, . . . [but] seem [not] to have supervised, the production of his juvenile attempts,” pointing to the evidence of only rare intervention parental intervention in the texts themselves: “In only two or three instances a word has been crossed out, and an emendation substituted by his father; but in several places his father and mother have inserted dates into the note-books, or endorsed a loose sheet ‘Johnʼs Poetry,’ (Date )” (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:261; Poems [8o, 1891], 1:262). Collingwood is correct about the evidence in the major manuscripts, but the family letters suggest a more complex story about parental supervision. Margaret Ruskin did attempt (not always successfully) to control Ruskinʼs behavior of imaginative writing—for example, the length of time he devoted to poetry, or the completion of goals the boy set for himself—but appears to have exercised less control over the writing’s content. John James Ruskin occasionally took his wifeʼs cues in enforcing discipline over behavior, but transparently half-heartedly, and he was more collusive than controlling respecting content. The boy was probably largely self-governing in regulating content.
